nodes.bodyText: s.o.
Should this be bound to the framework?

Nope, this doesn't do any harm if onboarding isn't used. Also there is not "a framework" ut actually two implementations (one for jdbc and one for mongo). Therefore we commonly don't check for a framework but rather if there is an impl for "OnboardingEngine" present...
This will give a nullpointer. Some lines above is an extra check against onboardingEngine being null so its expected that it can be null?
Should this be bound to the framework?

Nope, the routes have super low priorities and can easily overwritten if needed. If the OnboardingEngine is missing (no framework present), this will fail gracefully - as it shouldn't be called anyway).
Optional: Link the onboarding / academy class

Why is this class a mixture of all possible ways to handle when onboardingEngine is null? Some routes handle it gracefully with default/fallback values, some assert and fail and some just do nothing. Can this be cleaned up a bit?

Can we move the public API of the class to the top of provided methods?
So:

public
protected
private

Or are there good points that speak against this order in general? Just curious

I commonly put a (public) API method followed by the private helper method which are used there. The class itself is layouted along its "lifecycle":

fetch academie videos from provider
support multiplying academy videos into onboarding videos
query and show onboarding videos
maintain staticstics for onboarding videos

a (public) API method followed by the private helper method which are used there
Yes thats perfectly fine in my eyes. But even regarding this there are protected and public Methods mixed.

The lifecycle idea is a good one but when thinking about what I am looking for when I first open a framework class is its public API as I want to get a list of all methods that I can call on the class.
The next thing could be that I want to extend the class, meaning I want a list of all abstract classes. And so on ...
But I dont want to start a big discussion about this, the most important part is that the while public API and the internal abstract API has documentation 👍
